title: AB 1228
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature aims to encourage higher education institutions to provide information to foster care agencies about admissions and financial aid. They also urge the University of California and California State University to consider using admissions-by-exemption for homeless and foster youth. Each campus of the California Community Colleges with student housing facilities is requested to prioritize current and former homeless and foster youth for housing. The California Community Colleges prioritize current and former homeless and foster youth for housing in facilities open year-round at no extra cost during breaks, giving priority based on the number of days available for occupation. Each campus of the California Community Colleges is requested to develop a plan to ensure that current and former homeless youth and foster youth can access housing resources as needed, regardless of whether the campus has student housing facilities. (c) A "homeless youth" is defined as a student under 25 years old who has been verified as homeless within the past 24 months by a homeless services provider. The text discusses the eligibility criteria for students to be considered as former homeless youth for a period of six years from the date of admission. Additionally, it mentions the specific individuals who can verify this status, including the director of federal TRIO programs, Gaining Early Awareness and Readiness for Undergraduate Programs program, and financial aid administrators. Each campus of the California State University must prioritize current and former homeless youth and foster youth for student housing. The California State University campuses prioritize current and former homeless youth and foster youth for student housing, providing year-round accommodation at no extra cost during breaks. Priority is given to these groups for housing available for the most days in a year. Each California State University campus is asked to create a plan to ensure homeless and foster youth have access to housing resources during academic terms and breaks, regardless of student housing availability. A "homeless youth" under 25 years old, verified as homeless within the past 24 months, can be admitted to a California State University campus. Verification can be done by a homeless services provider. The Education Code is amended to include provisions for former homeless youth to retain their status for six years from admission. Each campus of the University of California with student housing facilities must prioritize current and former homeless youth and foster youth for housing. This includes giving them priority for year-round residence in housing facilities eligible for uninterrupted occupation. The University of California campuses prioritize current and former homeless youth and foster youth for year-round housing in eligible facilities, at no extra cost during breaks, and give them priority for residence for the most days in the calendar year. The University of California campuses prioritize current and former homeless youth and foster youth for year-round housing in eligible facilities, at no extra cost during breaks, and give them priority for residence for the most days in the calendar year. Additionally, a UC campus is asked to create a plan for homeless and foster youth to access housing resources as needed during academic terms and breaks, regardless of housing facilities availability. A "homeless youth" under 25 years old, verified as homeless within the past 24 months, is eligible for admission to a University of California campus. Verification can be done by a homeless services provider. The eligibility criteria for admission to a University of California campus for a homeless youth under 25 years old includes verification by a homeless services provider. Additionally, certain individuals such as the director of federal TRIO programs, financial aid administrators, and former homeless youth verified under specific conditions are also included in the eligibility criteria. The status of a former homeless youth is retained for six years from the date of admission. The University of California is subject to this section unless the Regents make it inapplicable through a resolution.
